Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Impact of Mild Renal Dysfunction in CABG Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at Nanjing First Hospital from July 2020 to December 2022.

Participants.evidence: Patients undergoing isolated CABG were divided into normal renal function (eGFR ≥ 90 mL/min/1.73 m²) and mild renal dysfunction (eGFR: 60–89 mL/min/1.73 m²) groups.

Intervention.evidence: Patients undergoing isolated CABG were divided into normal renal function (eGFR ≥ 90 mL/min/1.73 m²) and mild renal dysfunction (eGFR: 60–89 mL/min/1.73 m²) groups.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the prognosis and mid-term outcomes in CABG patients with mild renal dysfunction.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was acute kidney injury (AKI) within 7 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not applicable due to the retrospective nature of the study.

Blinding.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not applicable due to the retrospective nature of the study.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 1,097 patients were enrolled, with 416 (33.3%) having mild renal dysfunction.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Patients with mild renal dysfunction had a higher incidence of AKI (26.1% vs. 18.7%, p = 0.015) but no significant difference in perioperative mortality (1.3% vs. 1.3%, p = 1.00).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were not specifically reported.
